author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 4, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1711770726}
review:
Tribal Pass is yet another of several hundred, if not thousands of low effort endless runners plaguing Steam.

Like all endless/autorunners, you're moving and you can't stop.  All you can do is avoid the obstacles coming at you in this incredibly shallow shovelware game.  But there's a bit of a difference here as the game features a couple of different mechanics... which, while novel, don't actually improve anything in the old, dead formula.  What differences?  Instead of a single runner, you control a group of tribesmen (and a special "shaman" who holds all the "xp", if he dies that's reset).  You split the tribesmen, which has a couple of effects... it influences whether animals will be afraid of you or not, and it pushes tribesmen into different lanes... there's obstacles like bridges and so on, and your tribesmen need to be aligned to those lanes.  Likewise there's bushes and animals and you have to ensure your tribesmen hit them to gather stuff.

Speaking of gathering, there's our second gimmick... a food counter.  If that runs out, you die, so you need to gather food.  You do this by first aligning you tribesmen through the "split/join" mechanic, and you also need to equip a tool to do it.  There's 5 different tools for different pickups/hazards, like torches so you can see at night, empty hands to gather berries, a spear to kill deer things for meat, and so on.

Again, it's a gimmick that makes this more than your average endless runner, but it doesn't make it any better or more fun.  Let's get into the technical defects. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

A choice was made to use obsolete, decades old retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget or talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result.

While there are options to change the resolution for the game, all this does is scale up the simplistic 2D art assets used to make the game, which makes little or no difference to the graphics quality.  Without any other substantial graphics tweaks, it's not possible for gamers to improve the lacklustre 2D visuals.

The controls can't be customised because the game has such a dumbed down, simplified interface that it's just point and click stuff like a browser/Flash game.  The fact that the interface is this dumbed down might be seen as a problem in itself, however... this is a fairly shallow experience if you're the kind of gamer that likes to play games with deep, rich control schemes and interaction.  You'll get none of that here.

Because this is designed for consoles, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the inferior console gaming appliances that the game was designed for.  These are unfortunate compromises and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was a second thought for the console-centric developers.  The game is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for consoles forces upon a game.  Once more, console peasants have made gaming worse for everyone.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

Tribal Pass didn't appeal much to the people who own a copy of the game, either.  It has achievements, and they show us a very clear picture that the game didn't really capture any interest from gamers.  The most commonly and easily attained achievement is for finishing the tutorial, trivial to get, but less than 13 percent of players bothered to get that far before uninstalling the game.  Hardly a success story, gamers just weren't all that interested in the game.

Reviewing SteamDB to check how popular this game was with players reveals a surprise... there's a very healthy spike in player counts for the game.  But this only happened once, and isn't consistent with the achievement stats, that show less than 13 percent of players bothered playing the game for any reasonable amount of time.  How is it possible for this game to have so many concurrent players who didn't bother engaging with this game?  Trading cards.  People will use card idling software to collect the cards and sell them, but this won't trigger any achievements in-game.

That tells us people only really bought this game for trading cards, and that's a damning indictment of the woeful quality.  A closer look at the numbers shows the game just has a couple of players every week running up the game and idling it for cards, then deleting it.  We must ask how it benefits gamers for there to be so many games like this, with little merit as a serious game, that only generate sales from people idling and selling the trading cards.

So, should you buy this game?

Tribal Pass has the insane price of around $7 USD, it's not worth it given the defects and shortcomings with the product, especially considering the sheer number of completely free, much higher quality games on Steam.  For comparison, the $7 asking price for this game could get you games like "Portal 2", "Fallout 4" or "DOOM".  Quality, professionally made games like those are frequently on sale cheaper than this.

author: {'steamid': '76561199010042150', 'num_games_owned': 3874, 'num_reviews': 2454, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1705775486}
review:
I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right handâ€”the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bedâ€”the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075324976', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 689, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1701500374}
review:
This is a fun little running game with a twist, but it is still just a runner.
---

Instead of being a single person running in a direction, you're the entire tribe.

Screen moves in one direction (running down, screen moves up with your group at the top facing down). You have controls for changing the formation of your group into different running channels and what weapon/tool they have in their hands. You have to collect food (by changing group formation and/or tools) and avoid obstacles while also managing food and group size while some people die and new recruits are brought in. Survive with at least some tribe members and you pass the day and carry on to the next landscape to run through.

Complete enough days and you unlock another campaign "story" (not that there's any real story beyond "we run that direction to survive, follow the shaman")

It requires some quick thinking, sacrifices to be made, and a little luck to overcome some of the random layouts that don't always provide enough food. Compared to other runners you're making quick tactical formation and weapon decisions rather than making turns or jumps.
---

Bottom line: It can be a fun little time waster, but it is ultimately still just a runner.
---

L'objectif ? Rejoindre un nouveau lieu plus propice pour s'Ã©tablir dans la durÃ©e.

Durant vos courses vous devrez tuer Ã  l'aide de vos lances des cerfs, faire attention aux rhinocÃ©ros, aux fauves, aux ptÃ©rodactyles... ne pas tomber dans l'eau (ils ne savent pas nager!), dans les sables mouvants, rÃ©colter des baies, recruter (ou pas!) des nouveaux groupes d'hommes...
Vos premiers run seront difficiles, mais vous apprendrez au fur et Ã  mesure quelques astuces pour ne plus perdre 90% de votre tribu... (on ne recrute pas de nouveaux hommes avec des lances Ã  la main, ou vous pouvez effrayer les fauves avec les torches par exemple...)

Graphiquement Ã§a pique un peu les yeux bien sur, on est sur un jeu pixels complÃ¨tement assumÃ©, mais le thÃ¨me Ã©tait, pour moi, suffisamment fort pour que je m'y attele assez vite.

Petit point sur les succÃ¨s rien de trÃ¨s compliquÃ©, il vous faudra entre 1 et 3 heures pour en venir Ã  bout. Certains ne sont pas si Ã©vident, mais la plupart de dÃ©verrouilleront sans que vous ne le fassiez vraiment exprÃ¨s.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131414661', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1660436340}
review:
[b]WHAT YOU CAN DO, IT'S NOT EASY[/b]

[h1]6.4
ALL GOOD[/h1]

The time has come when you need to manage a tribe to the better place. They are need to move because need a safe place. First time seeing this kind of game, it's unique. When they are just walking automatically, you must make them save in every obstacle. Simple game and interesting. 3 different map and resources, you must be creative to finding foods and avoid some wild animal. Your enemies is your people, when you don't have enough food, they will starving and died one by one. A mix feeling when you can turn them into cannibal to stay alive. This is enjoy game.

[+]
- UNIQUE CONCEPT
- ENJOYABLE
- GOOD GRAPHIC
- NO PROBLEM ON ACHIEVEMENT
- BEAT THE TOP SCORER

[-]
- SHORT GAME
- NO STORY AND BASIC EXPLANATION
- CLASSIC BGM
- AFTER PLAY, LOOK AROUND AND YOU SEE EVERYTHING UP AND DOWN (MUSIC RHYTHM GAME MOMENT)

Tribal Pass, all you have to do is move your people to a better place. Quite simple game that you can enjoy. Trophies are achievable, you can strike get it all. In my case, there is no problem but much lucky moment to get it. Using a mouse is more easier than trackpad, because it's my case that can't use a mouse because malfunctioned USB issue. Thanks for reading, hope you guys have fun~ :)

review: A very simple game, but addictive with a neat visual style and a decent bit of challenge. Think an infinite runner mixed with the resource management and map travel of Oregon Trail. I paid $4.79 and feel happy with what I'm getting for the price of a burger or two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198444101910', 'num_games_owned': 167, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 162, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 162, 'last_played': 1649936361}
review:
[h1] YANOGA REVIEW [/h1]

[b][u] GRAPHICS -  â˜… â˜… â˜† â˜† â˜† [/u][/b]
''Tribal Pass'' is a pixel-art runner game. While it have a good colour variation its not pretty beautiful even for a game that's made with Unity.

[b][u] MUSIC - â˜… â˜† â˜† â˜† â˜† [/u][/b]
The same sound loop going over and over again. (And not even a good one...)

[b][u] STORY -  â˜… â˜† â˜† â˜† â˜† [/u][/b]
The Earth gets destroyed from a asteroid and a shaman and his tribesmen must run trough the villiages to save the world. Well thats what the first and only 30 second ''cut-picture'' will tell you about anything which is about a ''story''

[b][u] GAMEPLAY -  â˜… â˜† â˜† â˜† â˜†  [/u][/b]
Tribal Pass is a runner game. You running down with a couple of tribesmen and need to split them while running or chance if they got nothing in their hands to pick up berries or speers to hunt animals. Thats everything. 
You probably guessed right that a game that can be summarized in one sentence will also be just making fun for one playtrough. And thats the case with this game. It functions and I respect every dev for making their own games but this one is just so terrible mediocre that you will be better off playing every other Steam Game under 5â‚¬ which is on Sale right now.

[b][u] WORTH BUYING - â˜… â˜† â˜† â˜† â˜† [/u][/b]
If you want to play a runner game than there a two options. 1) Go on your smartphone and play one of the 10000000 runner games on it or 2) Go on a harsh search for a good runner game on steam. Unfortunately Tribal Pass is not such a good game - just a sandcorn in the sahara of games that will never be picked out and surely will be forgotten when time chances. This game will bring you a maximum of 1 hour of fun.


[b][u]    LENGTH [/u][/b]          : Played 2 Hours 

[b][u]    BUGS    [/u][/b]      : No
  
 [b][u]     PRICE [/u][/b]       : Paid 1.99â‚¬ 
  
 [b][u]     DIFFICULTY [/u][/b] : Normal - Hard

[h1] FINAL:

author: {'steamid': '76561198110813524', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 239, 'last_played': 1611875318}
review: Tribal Pass is quite enjoyable, however with a price tag of Â£5.19 it just isn't worth it. Although the mechanics are sort of well thought out the game does not do a good job of telling you what to do in different situations. This lead to me trying to decode what just happened when I picked up some cavemen on the way at one campfire, only to then have half my squad wiped out at the next. This could be good if there were some obvious hints, but there isn't really, and if you're accidently doing something and you don't know what it is then it can be very confusing. Overall its alright, but not worth the price tag, if its on sale then go for it though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054674251', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1608997036}
review:
7 out of 14 achievements in under 29 minutes.

This game has a high art production quality, but the gameplay is your basic crowd-run flash game. I didn't have much fun with it, and after beating the single run, I have no desire to play the "Big Pass". 

Pass.

author: {'steamid': '76561198184897393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 653, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1584149513}
review:
Mixed (due to price, though I got it in a bundle). A short runner game, fun in short spurts. Two different modes do not really add much variety, but it is a highscore chaser more than anything else. Fun for a few hours, but hard to justify the standard asking price unless you really love this type of game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016324311', 'num_games_owned': 585, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1577363616}
review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
A top-down runner game with limited replayability but interesting theme. Worth getting on a sale or as a bundle but otherwise there's not much on offer here.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The premise of the game is fairly simple: Avoid impending doom by crossing a number of zones with your tribe and keeping at least some of them alive by the end. The game is played from a top-down perspective and your tribe advances automatically. You have two main mechanics to help you do this Firstly, splitting or joining the group into halves will allow it to cover more area and avoid obstacles, which is required to bypass or interact with most of the obstacles in your path. The second mechanic is a series of actions your tribe can do such as equipping spears or torches, both of which lead to different interactions with the environment. In addition, you can create new tribesmen or cannibalize existing ones for food. 

Food is the main limiting factor of a run, as it depletes constantly according to your tribe's size and most of your environmental interactions that don't involve avoiding danger will be focused on gathering this essential resource, whether they involve hunting animals (or fellow tribesmen), picking berries or sacrificing your tribe at an altar. Between zones, you will receive a token which allows you to claim a one-time bonus and you have a choice of two zones for your next segment of the run with some variation in resources and threats, therefore offering a small amount of tactical decision-making based on your available resources.

All that said, the game has an interesting concept but a lackluster execution. Procedural generation means that, more often than not, a set of obstacles or simply the lack of food sources means your tribe will end up starving, often even during the first zone. The zones also don't really offer any surprises after going through them once or twice and learning how to deal with the various obstacles. The resource management aspect of the game could be great if elaborated upon or if the player had more influence on it compared to random chance but as it stands there's not a big reason to come back to it. This is one of those games where a neutral rating would be appropriate but as it stands I'd only really recommend it as part of a bundle, sale or other such deal.

[h1]Visuals & Audio[/h1]
The visual and audio design work well to convey the various obstacles in your path in a clear manner but there's not much else to say that the screenshots of the game won't reveal to you. Music-wise, the tribal soundtrack is fitting and enhances the experience but didn't feel especially noteworthy or memorable to me.

[h1]Completion[/h1]
Completion is a simple affair and can be done in a fairly short amount of time. Most of the achievements can be gotten either during regular gameplay or with a small amount of effort on the player's part and they cover most of what you can do in the game without overstaying their welcome.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989290281', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 315, 'playtime_forever': 47, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 47, 'last_played': 1566843714}
review:
https://youtu.be/aDtUUsi7Rus

The idea itself is an interesting twist on the runner genre. Whilst the graphics and sound are good sadly the gameplay itself is not. 

Basically you are totally at the mercy of RNG each time you play. And more often than not the RNG is not in your favour leaving the game with little in the way of fair or balanced levels. Add in some slightly cumbersome controls and the game quickly loses its appeal. 

For a bit more work on the balance this could have been a great little diversion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009316076', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1566343438}
review: Not often I give a game a negative review. But this one warrants it. I bought it quite a while back and only got to it this evening. It's not a terrible game. But it's not really all that good. The concept is novel. You are basically in a series of stages in an endless runner, with the idea that you're supposed to make tactical decisions along the way. You split your tribe into groups to cross bridges, gather berries, and hunt animals. You need to equip spears to hunt, but animals run from large groups. You need to use torches to kill flies before they eat your food. Stuff like that. However everything is randomly generated. You could go a decent section of map without finding any food. Oh, and I did I mention your tribe starts dying of starvation if you don't have enough food? Yeah that's a thing. There's also bonfires where you're meant to add to your tribe but it seems totally RNG whether or not you get them or they just kill your own people. It seems like a good concept. But it didn't do a thing for me. I've only played for approximately half an hour, but trust me, that's all you really need to see to determine if this game is fun (it's really not). I would refund it if I could and I paid very little for this.

review:
At the first glare game picked up my intrest. After few runs i started to get annoyed. At the end i am feeling dissapointed, didn't enjoy the game at all. Probably not a kind of game for my likings but still not terrible game. Since i bought it on discount at really low price i shouldn't complain ...
Well, i can say the design and idea is nice, that's all.
Get it if you want, i am not recommending.
[h1]Rate: 4/10[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197977112201', 'num_games_owned': 2752, 'num_reviews': 143, 'playtime_forever': 376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 376, 'last_played': 1537124016}
review:
Welcome to Tribal Run: A Tactical Runner with its own unique gameplay. It is unlike any other game in the genre. You are the Shaman who must lead your people to a safe area before the sky fire destroys your village. Along the way, you are faced with many dangers. From wild animals, rivers, fire, insects,quicksand, and others things that will kill off your tribe if you do not lead them in the proper formations. There is no stopping during your march across the lands, you must march forward ordering your people to change formation to avoid danger & collect much-needed food till nightfall, or your people will die off fast.

Released in later August 2016 by a collaboration of developers, including Tribe Tea, Stas Shostak, Evgeniy Yudin, Alexzander Protasenya, and Ruslan Viter and published by Stas Shostak. It is tagged as a Difficult, Action, Adventure, Runner, Indie title. The game holds up to the difficult tag, it will take a little time to get used to the mechanics of the game. The gameplay is fairly simple, using just your mouse to control the tribe's formations and the 1 thru 5 keys to control actions for the tribe. The game does have controller settings in the launcher even though controller support is not listed for the game. There is also a Leaderboard; Do you have what it takes to make it to the top of the list?

I would recommend you start with the Tutorial and get the basics of gameplay learned before you start the Single Run. Once you have the basics down it is time to play your first game. You will have a choice of multiple routes to get to the new grounds that your people are to call their new home. Along with choosing to run at night or day, day runs cost you needed food, so choose wisely. There are various Tokens you can enable at the start of your second level to help give you a little advantage. There are multiple language settings: EN, RU, ZH, EU, ES, PT, FR, IT. So you are able to read the dialog in your native language. Once you beat the Single Run, you will unlock the Big Pass gameplay, which varies from the Single Run. For Big Pass, you work to move all the people from your village as fast as possible before they starve to death. The balance of your resources become very critical in this game style.

With well-done Pixel Graphics, great sound effects and unique gameplay, for the asking price it is a nice little indie title to add to one's library. There is a medium replayability for the title. Though the title really is not very long. With unlocking the second play style and multiple routes for both the game styles, these options will give you continued play for a while. For you achievement hunters, the game has 14 achievements with most of them unlocking during normal gameplay, you can 100% them fairly easily.

I had a rather hard start with the game myself. After about 30 minutes of trial and error, I got a good grasp on the gameplay and was able to beat the Single Run for my first time and unlock the Big Pass. It was very satisfying when I beat it for the first time. I am currently trying to finish the Big Pass, as promised the game is Difficult. But I will finish this title one way or another. I am having fun playing, even when I get annoyed at my misclicks from time to time. I may cuss and rage at times, but my goal is obtainable as I continue to get used to the flow of the game. My worse problem with the game is the night play, I am half blind, half deaf & half crazy :P and games with a lot of darkness give me a harder time playing them. Though it does not stop me in the least from playing my heart out still. I will stop gaming when they pry my cold dead fingers from the keyboard LoL.

Now is your time to decide. Can you lead your people to safety?

7/10

Tribal Run: A Difficult Pixel Runner: Are you worthy to be the Shaman!

Pro's
+Steam Trading Cards
+Steam Achievements
+Challenging Gameplay

Cons
-No Volume Control Options

[quote]Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

review: A unique tactical runner game where you have to decide things in split second. I've never played a runner game this involved before. Your tribe size is your strength and your health, but bigger tribe means you're easier to hurt and you need more food. You often have to decide which part of the tribe you're going to sacrifice. It's simple, hard, and you'll die all the time, but each run only take three minutes or something, so you play this when you're bored and waiting for your instant noodle to finish or whatever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009474997', 'num_games_owned': 2217, 'num_reviews': 1072, 'playtime_forever': 589, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 517, 'last_played': 1531485296}
review:
a Literal runner,so beware this game is all about non stop running, so make sure this is something you will play before buying it.

Tribal runner isn't a bad game i just think most wot like it because of the game type, the game can be fun but again most people most like it or enjoy it as much.
It's a different kind of survival game that is for sure, the game is very long but it has enjoyable gameplay. The game offers decent graphics and visuals.  The gameplay itself can offer quite a challenge so dont expect to hit everything in one go.

For the price this is not a bad game, so check out the videos and then decide whether to give it a go or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198356141989', 'num_games_owned': 2521, 'num_reviews': 637, 'playtime_forever': 1742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1500, 'last_played': 1511652971}
review:
A tactical runner?
Oh, well..
A nice indie one! :)
This game's premises are quite simple - you've got to collect food for your tribe (hence the original name of the game, simply entitled The Tribe, but that's another story) in order not to let it die, through the days.
With its nice retro graphics, you'll be able of course to make many actions to get your goal. You'll be required to kill enemies  in order to get food, but you'll also be able to pick up from the ground berries and such.
With the left mouse button, you'll split your tribe in half - the tactical elements are quite nice - and in other halves, in order to avoid obstacles (you'll have for instance to cross rivers in selected numbers) and prehistorical enemies, get some food, kill enemies and so on in a different way. With the right mouse button you'll be able, always in a runner environment, to reunite the tribe again.
As I was saying, the basic controls are linked to keyboard buttons and apart from hunting animals and grabbing resources you'll also be able to light torches to see through the night (endless runner from day to night of course xD) or even increase your fellow tribesmen (if you've got enough resources). Sometimes, it will also be needed to kill some of your characters in order not to have too many guys around you and save resources.
I really liked the graphics and the historical environment, and also the changes from night to day and the different challenges with torches and so on, lighting up around you or scaring enemies and such.
And I also liked a lot the user interface - the buttons you can press are clearly shown in the upper side of the screen, and since the game won't ever get too fast you'll always manage somehow to balance food, "population" and the actions you'll have to do.
The main issue of such a game of course relies in its replayability - being an indie title, it's not that long and when you have explored every part of the game (the environments, the enemies, your actions, the night/day system, the point system after each day etc.) you're basically done. There's nothing more, and you need to love "endless" games in order to fully enjoy this title.
Still, for some hours it's a solid indie game and it adds some new and nice things greatly blended in the game setting. The options may be limited, but it's worthy to explore them all and build some levels :)
I didn't see a lack of tactical elements, as someone pointed out. You've got to manage lots of resources, to keep eyes on your tribesmen dying, to choose between spears, hands or torches, to split up and reunite your tribe and to get through the night to the other side of the map.
It's not that easy, but it's somehow addicting for many hours. The lack of a proper plot and, more than all, real trophies and accomplishments to obtain of course is something that goes against this title - it's just endless, without a real ending or even bosses or such. But the developers themselves said that it was supposed to be as it is, and in my view it's a very nice title. Tactical, endless and runner :P
I forgot to say something about the soundtrack, which matches the prehistorical environment but it's not that great - probably, the 2â‚¬/$ for the OST and the artwork aren't greatly spent if you don't get them as a gift or in some bundles, since they include only few musical tracks (extremely short, 15 minutes in total or even less) and all the game artwork, which is good in-game but has little use outside of it.
I think that if you like survival games based on an endless and somehow "tactical" engine, this one is a great game. It's for sure worth a try even if you're not into this genre, since it's greatly made (ok, just some spelling errors I think, I played only in English) and everything (tutorial included) works perfectly, as the developers wanted Tribal Pass to be.
The lack of upgrades/bonuses too doesn't help for the replayability issue, but still it's worth it in my opinion. I think you'll like it, you just have to be prepared and read something about it since the game will offer you everything you're reading here (I hope) and in other players' way better reviews than mine. 
You won't find many surprises in the endless night/day levels but still there's plenty of options and everything works perfectly, I didn't find bugs of any sort. 
I read many early access reviews, but fortunately now (and when I played it) is fully available and so don't worry about anything - if you like these premises you'll be addicted for some hours, just give yourself half an hour to fully understand the mechanics.. and have fun :)

review:
[h1][b]Nous sommes Ã  l'Ã¢ge de pierre.[/b]
Pierre ? PrÃ©sent. Pierre ? PrÃ©sent ! Pierre ? PrÃ©sente. Pierre ? ... PIERRE ?[/h1]

[i][b]Tribal Pass[/b][/i] Â«est un jeu de type â€runnerâ€ [strike]trÃ¨s difficile[/strike] basÃ© sur la gestion de ressources et les intÃ©ractions avec lâ€™environnement â€“ en pleine course.Â» C'est ce que dit la description du magasin, et c'est tout Ã  fait Ã§a.
Cependant je vous rassure tout de suite, il n'est pas "trÃ¨s difficile". Bien sÃ»r, au dÃ©but on Ã©choue encore et encore, mais on comprend vite la plupart des subtilitÃ©s du jeu dans la premiÃ¨re heure passÃ©e Ã  y jouer.

Alors comment Ã§a se passe ? C'est trÃ¨s simple. Notre tribu occupe le haut de l'Ã©cran et va parcourir le niveau sans s'arrÃªter, jusqu'Ã  atteindre la fin dudit niveau. Nous, on va faire en sorte que la tribu passe avec succÃ¨s les 5 niveaux consÃ©cutifs en lui faisant Ã©viter les obstacles et la famine.

D'abord, il va constamment falloir diviser et regrouper la tribu pour Ã©viter les prÃ©dateurs et les riviÃ¨res, atteindre la nourriture, etc... Avec le clic droit, on divise la tribu. Si on clique une fois, on divise la tribu en 2 groupes. Si on reclique, celle-ci se divisera en 3. Puis en 4 si on clique encore, et ainsi de suite. Inversement, avec le clic gauche, on regroupe la tribu. Donc si elle est divisÃ©e en 6, un clic gauche la ramÃ¨nera Ã  5 groupes. Il faudra cliquer 4 fois supplÃ©mentaires pour la rÃ©unir en un seul groupe. VoilÃ  pour les mouvements.

Ensuite, tout en divisant et regroupant la tribu, il va falloir utiliser 5 "outils" Ã  notre disposition. En mangeant, le chaman qui mÃ¨ne la tribu va gagner de l'expÃ©rience et rapidement dÃ©bloquer ces outils. On commence de base avec la "main" qui servira Ã  cueillir les fruits pour gagner de la nourriture. Puis viendra la lance, permettant de chasser/combattre. En troisiÃ¨me, la torche qui sert entre autre Ã  Ã©clairer la nuit (elle sert aussi Ã  d'autres choses). En quatriÃ¨me, on dÃ©bloque le cannibalisme, c'est-Ã -dire tuer des membres de la tribu pour obtenir de la nourriture. Et enfin en cinquiÃ¨me et dernier, l'inverse, c'est-Ã -dire Ã©changer de la nourriture pour aggrandir la tribu en pleine course. L'ordre Ã  son importance car on ne peut accÃ©der au cannibalisme (4) sans avoir d'abord dÃ©bloquÃ© la torche (3). Le dÃ©blocage se fait automatiquement. On sÃ©lÃ©ctionne ces outils avec les touches "1", "2", "3", "4", et "5". Chaque Ã©lÃ©ment rencontrÃ© dans la course rÃ©agit diffÃ©remment en fonction de "l'outil" qu'on utilise.
Ah oui, si le chaman meurt, un autre le remplace, mais son expÃ©rience revient Ã  zÃ©ro et il faut Ã  nouveau tout redÃ©bloquer (ce qui va trÃ¨s vite).

Au final, [i][b]Tribal Pass[/b][/i] est un petit jeu bien sympathique sur lequel on passe agrÃ©ablement quelques heures. En me fixant comme objectif d'obtenir tous les succÃ¨s, j'ai mis deux heures pour en faire le tour. Les fanas du score pourront y passer plus de temps et chercher Ã  atteindre la tÃªte du classement, mais pour les autres, le temps de jeu sera assez court. Mais sympa. TrÃ¨s sympa.

review:

There are many way better 1 euro games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063549777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1514678270}
review:
"Tactical runner" does sum it up nicely. It's nice to figure out the behaviors of things in the environment and trying to react accordingly. It's got a nice dynamic, alternating the tasks of your little tribesmen and considering your path through the map or what power-ups you'll try to earn and use.

On the other hand, it doesn't have a lot of mileage. I beat this in an hour and a half, all achievements included. Grab it on a big sale, if you're curious. It's not much, but it's a cool challenge if you can get into the rhythm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081999502', 'num_games_owned': 640, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1511985789}
review:
Un simple juego de scroll. El concepto es algo original pero fuera de eso no tiene mucha historia o musica. 

El arte es bueno si te gustan los juegos de 8bits y si es retador llevar a tu tribu a travez de 5 mapas hasta la salvacion.

y esta totalmente al espaÃ±ol, siempre mega bueno.

Al principio, este juego te podrÃ¡ parecer super dificil, asi que yo aconsejo matar a tu tribu ahogandola o algo asi hasta que tengas menos de 8 monos, asi serÃ¡ mas facil que no se te mueran de hambre mientras que aprendes a cambiar de lanza a mano a antorcha y como dividir y juntar a tus monitos.

Los logros son faciles, yo los saque al 100% en 3 horas, el mas dificil era juntar 10 grupos de campamento, ya que necesitas algo de suerte a que te salgan los 10 grupos en una sola corrida sin usar tokens azules.

Pero una vez que acabas tu primera corrida, una nueva opcion en el menu sale donde podras empezar corridas con 1500 comidas y 40 monos, con esto, es facil correr para juntar grupos de campamentos y otros logros locos que hay.

Si esta en oferta, lo recomiendo para pasar el rato y sacarlo al 100% pero no es aca mega bueno para que lo tengas que comprar, esta.. "bien".

A este juego le doy 50 moras envenedadas de 4 p*tos terodacitles que no puedes evadir.. inches vuitres mamalados de merde. >.<

author: {'steamid': '76561198087475757', 'num_games_owned': 1643, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1510029359}

author: {'steamid': '76561198078437944', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1552517899}
review:
Wow it looks like a mini game or one that you only play every now and then.
And I guess it is, BUT it has more depth than I thought. 
You get to make decisions about what your clan does WHILE its running, plus you have to dodge enemies and collect food on the run as well.
All this together really makes for a kind of fast paced strategy.
The graphics are simple but beautiful I think and the music is kind of funny too as it fits the game, with some drums accompanying you and your tribe running. 
All in all, a very nice little game that, as I already mentioned does offer more strategy depth and decision making than I thought. Therefore I do reall recommend it!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198273011256', 'num_games_owned': 3040, 'num_reviews': 715, 'playtime_forever': 275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 275, 'last_played': 1505513835}
review:
[h1]ok...[/h1]
Pues...  este juego es un "runner" en vertical (bastante dificil) en el cual tu objetivo es sobrevivir cada escena con tu chaman y varios hombres prehistoricos a diferencia de los "runners" clasicos llevas un grupo, manejas a una bola de cavernicolas los cuales tienen varias "skills" para sortear obstaculos; sacar lanzas, antorchas para la noche o incluso comer al projimo. 

[Ya que su "vida" es un contador de comida que tienes, si llega a cero vas perdiendo personitas en el camino; se mueren de hambre]

Sus fuertes:
-Gameplay sencillo
-arte bonito
-banda sonora adoc

lo meh:
-Pues... repetitivo como todos los runners. Si te gusta el estilo, muy recomendable.
-La dificultad, que el gameplay sea sencillo, el dominar las mecanicas del juego si es otra cosa xD

[h1]Resumiendo:[/h1]
Es un juego que vale un dolar... que cumple con lo que debe hacer todo juego: entretener. A la larga aburre; y tiene buena curva de dificultad, no es must buy a menos que te gusten mucho los runners. 
[ojo, que a mi me salio a un 10% de su precio, por crear una badge; por lo cual no me siento timada]

author: {'steamid': '76561198164948371', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 536, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 536, 'last_played': 1503691551}
review:
(Aclaro que lo recibÃ­ gratis porque hice la traducciÃ³n al espaÃ±ol).


Juego breve y sencillo. La mÃºsica estÃ¡ bien y la jugabilidad tambiÃ©n. La idea es muy simple: correr antes de que caiga un meteorito y saltar obstÃ¡culos, ya sean animales (aves, rinocerontes, insectos, etc.) o arbustos venenosos, rÃ­os u otras tribus (tambiÃ©n pueden integrarse a tu tribu, si tu numero es superior al suyo). 
Hay una suerte de campaÃ±a, en la que hay que ir venciendo los distintos territorios, ya sea de dÃ­a o de noche (hay menos visibilidad y conviene usar antorchas). 
Hay un chamÃ¡n que lidera a la tribu y conviene protegerlo. Para llegar al final, se necesita que tu gente haya superado todos los obstÃ¡culos y tenga el alimento suficiente para que no mueran de hambre. A mÃ¡s seguidores, mÃ¡s consumo de comida.
En las corridas se pueden recolectar unas fichas que otorgan comida, nuevos miembros  a la tribu o te permiten comenzar el nivel de nuevo si te derrotan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071616039', 'num_games_owned': 5698, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1501959635}
review: Short game with interesting gameplay mechanic, where you have to divide and regroup all the time your nomads to evade threats and collect bonuses while using some basic skils. The concept is great, but unfortunately the game lacks variety enough of scenarios, dangers and power-ups. Even being procedurally generated, levels become pretty repetitive soon. I recommend it because it was fun to play anyway for a couple hours, and because this game was included as part as a Humble Monthly Bundle (recommended if it comes included in a bundle or extremely cheap).

author: {'steamid': '76561198002460495', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1502315332}
review:
Really nice game, and nice developer too.

The gameplay is simple but well developed. It has a micro component (commanding your tribe across the land) and a macro component (plan ahead the amount of food you'll use and people you'll need). 

You learn by trying and losing, and although guides would come in handy, you're intended to figure out the mechanincs by yourself (and the author won't spoil you much about how to deal with X or Y), so bear that in mind. I'm not a smart player when it comes to trial and error; I find the lack of guides about game mechanics a bit frustratig but hey, it's completely fair.

Very good game, recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974694456', 'num_games_owned': 1517, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1497043851}
review:
This is a very casual and simple game. It's an interesting game on keeping your tribe alive and escaping fire. The control is very rough and could be better. It does get old and repetitive very fast. It feels like a flash game that you can play in a web browser. I would only recommend getting it at steep discount (90% off).

Pro
+ Interesting Gameplay

Con
- Rough Control

review:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=904685233

En clair, Tribal Pass est un jeu dans lequel votre but est celui de, accompagnÃ© de votre tribut d'hommes prÃ©historique, traverser une map parsemÃ©e d'embuches, tels que des feux, des animaux passifs ou non, et surtout des ruisseaux. Le tout se joue particuliÃ¨rement dans la rapiditÃ© des clics de souris, car le clic-gauche vous permet de rassembler vos hommes, tandis que le clic-droit vise Ã  les disperser, Ã©taler en de de plus petits groupes sur la largueur de la map, plus pratique pour rÃ©colter la nourriture ( trop importante ), et qui donc augmente le risque de subir des pertes humaines.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081430111', 'num_games_owned': 2542, 'num_reviews': 109, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1493164881}
review:
[h1]Tribal Pass is an automatic runner game  set in a prehistoric world. Run, hunt, pass over obstacles, and try to keep as many of your tribesman alive as you possibly can during your dangerous journey.  
[/h1]

Is this a bad game? No.

Is it fun? Debatable.

I wish I could give this a neutral review, but I can't--hence I'm sticking to a positive one with some caveats. If you're like me, you should probably avoid this game.

https://youtu.be/8oMrfQeCbxw

Runs are procedurally generated and this does not work in your favour--especially since the title claims to be tactical. There's no strategy that can save you from not being able to find food; pften times, you won't find enough to feed your tribesmen and they'll die. Even after thinning out your numbers in order to provide for the remaining members, it's still near-impossible to maintain enough food.

You can switch between bare hands, holding spears or torches, increasing your tribe numbers if you have enough food to sustain them, and even sacrificing members in order to create more food in a pinch.

Your run ends once you reach the other end of the map. Time passes when you run, so the next map will be played during the night if you first ran during the day and vice versa. There's the option to wait out the night, but this will cost more food than you'll likely have.

Unfortunately, night time is fraught with dangers and increases your risk of going hungry. In order to see what's in front of you in the slightest, you need to hold torches. Torches scare off animals and burn berry bushes, which means acquiring food will be even more difficult still. If you don't hold torches, however, you'll easily run into obstacles and predators and your tribe will die.

I have yet to see the tactical aspects of this game. There is resource management, sure, but the procedural generation makes it so that stockpiling anything is nigh impossible. Predators and other tribes will kill you on site and herbavores will run off unless you spread out your formation to groups of only a few spear-toting tribesman. Changing formation is often stilted by the environmental hazards, so I found it difficult to hunt if only because I'd smash into something shortly thereafter and kill half of my tribe.

There are no upgrades at all--none that can be earned during your run nor ones that carry over and make subsequent runs easier. As such, the procedural generation will continue to screw you until you're too frustrated to bother.

The game is presented in pixel art, which I'm a fan of. I also like the prehistoric theme. The music is a constant loop of tribal beats and I muted it after the first few minutes.

.Pros.
[list][*]Interesting mechanics like sacrificing tribe members in a pinch.
[*]Environment responds to what you carry in your hands.
[*] The gritty pixel art is suitable.[/list]

.Cons.
[list][*]The music is on a constant loop.
[*]The game relies almost entirely on luck due to its random generation.
[*] Huge difficulty curve with no permanent upgrades to help ease you in.[/list]

.Bottom Line.

For the price, you can do better. Runners are meant to be challenging, but typically you can memorize obstacles or you're given upgrades to make it so that you get a little further each time. Tribal Pass does neither and so it just becomes an exercise of frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119057120', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 266, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1488873272}
review:
Quite good dexterity based runner game.

Pros:
- it's fast - you need to think fast
- it's focused - the most important unit is the shaman, rest are just mere tools for highscore
- it's short - you can complete a single full run in under 30 minutes

Cons:
- it's ugly - graphics are really bad. Pixel art is OK but compare Hero Siege vs this game.

Overall - it's a pretty decent runner game where you need to quickly click mouse buttons to split or join your cavemen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094959684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 170, 'last_played': 1487252724}
review:
[h1][i]Game:[/i][/h1]
[i]Tribal Pass is a hardcore indie game with pixel graphics. The Controls are quite simple, hotkeys for actions (hand, spears, torches, cannibalism, food), left and right click for separation of the group... with a boring gameplay. - [b]4/10[/b][/i]

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
+ Minimum Requirements Very Low.
+ Cheap Price.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- Very Unbalanced.
- No Adjustable Volume (On/Off).
- Quickly Gets Boring.

[h1]Personal Opinion:[/h1]
It's a good game only if you want spend some time.

[i]Written for Curator Group, Trump Giveaways.[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198008549198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 576, 'playtime_forever': 189, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1486794708}
review:
Pretty original game. Very simple concept: you control a running tribe, being able to:
- split it or gather it to cover particular grounds
- equip it with lances, torches or bare hands
- grow the tribe (increasing its food consumption) or sacrifice tribesmen (to get food when you ran out)
And with this, you must deal with various dangers and bring as many tribesmen to the end of the level. Sounds easier than it actually is ;)

An advice for beginners: don't overgrow your tribe. Actually, I found that the easiest way to finish a level was to play with just a few tribesmen: this way at least you can hardly starve out.
But the more people you bring to the end, the higher your score, so eventually you'll have to put that into the balance if you want to score high.

My main criticism would be the lack of a detailed guide or tutorial. There is a tutorial, but it's far from covering everything, so you'll have to also learn from game tips that appear occasionally or from experience. For instance:
- rhinos won't kill you if you don't have a weapon equipped
- flies will eat your food

author: {'steamid': '76561198094221272', 'num_games_owned': 3116, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1483224180}
review:
[i]Genre-twisting[/i] runner is really good term to describe [i]The Tribe[/i]. It has unusual game mechanics for this type of game. They are really simple when you look at them on paper; but when you start your run it is not at all rainbows and cupcakes; and it is prime example of game that looks easy, but is really hard to master.

You not only run forward to reach your goal, but you have to take care of your tribesmen in order to survive harsh environment they live in. You need (more than anything) food to feed your tribe.
No food = your unstoppable army of prehistoric people starts to die pretty quickly. 
Food can be obtained, by setting up the right formation so you can pick berries from bushes, killing a moose or other tribes ... in worst case scenario, you can degrade yourself to cannibalism with hope that you will survive until next level. Harder it is due to obstacles in your way. Rivers, quick sand; flies that will eat your food; bloodthirsty sabertooth, extremely tough rhyno - both can be killed (apparently), but with them in my way I found only death of my people. Easy ...
And doing this when night settles in and the darkness cover the whole world ... easy peasy.
*stares into the wall, reflecting on many, many, many deaths, and failed runs*

[i]The Tribe[/i] is for me really frustrating, because I am not skillful enough and patient enough to get good in this game, and complete it. I make a lot of mistakes by missclicking, wrongly evaluating situation ahead of me ... and all of this is only my issue. Game itself runs well, controls well, there is nothing wrong with it - something is wrong with me, obviously.

Technically is pretty alright game, nothing stands out really - negatively or positively - that would need special mention. 

Overall it is a nice, little, neat game, where you can get easily lost and kill couple hours, if it fits into your wheelhouse.
I encourage YOU to give this game a fair chance. It might surprise you.

[i]Grade:[/i][b] C+[/b]

review: This game is a fun, fantastic runner. Keeping your tribe alive as opposed to just yourself adds a dimension of play requiring you to choose the right tools, nab food, light the way or hunt animals in order to survive. You can add new people to your tribe, but sometimes they join voluntarily, and sometimes they impale a portion of the tribe on their spears and laugh at you. VERY addictive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961150231', 'num_games_owned': 2891, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1474226245}
review:
I also covered this game on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RiO2ximd-Wk

The Tribe has some cool ideas in it and tries to take the runner genre in a cool direction but it has some major issues that have only been partially address since Early Access. I think it's worth $5 but only if you're into the specific twist it's offering.

The basics are that you're a tribal leader who is trying to lead your gaggle of cavemen to a mountain on the other side of the world. You have to go through a number of levels to get there, each of which is randomly generated and can be made up of several environment types with different risks and benefits. The randomness of the level generation can sometimes be very unfair but that's the nature of the beast. Your tribe is always running and you can spread them out to various different pre-determined positions and retract them using the mouse buttons. You have to acquire food and grow your tribe as you go but the more tribesmen you have, the more food you burn. However, the more tribesmen you have, the more dangerous creatures and situations you can handle.

You have several abilities you can trigger and retract using the number keys. You have spears which have to be out to hunt animal food but will destroy fruit and scare the animals away if you have them out when on the same row as them. You also have fire which you'll need to scare some bigger creatures away and light the way at night, which you'll sometimes have to run through if you don't have enough food. You can also spend some of your food reserves to grow your tribe or cannibalise some tribesmen to get some emergency food. Yep, there's cannibalism in this game. You'll also encounter other small tribes and if you're big enough, you can recruit them or kill them for food as well.

Unfortunately, you're never really told how many tribesmen are needed to deal with the various threats you'll come across. This requires a lot of frustrating trial and error and will cost you many runs as you try to figure it out. The patterns your tribesmen take with different mouse clicks is also not made clear and this also takes a lot of practice and memorisation. Beyond this, not much needs to be explained to you, which is good because what English is in The Tribe is very poorly translated and some of it just makes no sense. There were larger, largely text based encounters that took place in between missions in Early Access that have been removed, I assume partially because of these translation difficulties.

The music and sound effects are fitting of the era being depicted in The Tribe. I originally didn't like the art style but it grew on me with time and I think that will come down to personal taste. The game runs fine, though its leaderboard implementation is not especially great.

For $5, I do still recommend The Tribe, even with its faults. It's a good take on the runner genre with a unique setting and mechanics to match. If you don't like runner games and learning and adapting on your feet, this probably won't be for you. But if you like a challenge and something that rewards quick reflexes, definitely give it a shot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055725979', 'num_games_owned': 1326, 'num_reviews': 262, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1474995717}
review:

Entre los elementos que aparecen en el camino podemos contar con los que nos dan y quitan comida y los que nos matan o nos dan hombres. Forman un cuadrado sin embargo solamente existirÃ¡ un elemento diferente para dos de sus puntos, y varios elementos para sus otros dos.
Entre las habilidades contaremos con tres de utilidad: recolecciÃ³n, caza y antorchas para afrontar el cuadrado, y dos avanzadas: sacrificios y hacer crecer a la tribu por medio de alimentos, sirviendo estas dos Ãºltimas de conexiÃ³n directa hacia su planteamiento bÃ¡sico.
Se cuenta como aliciente un chamÃ¡n que lidera a la tribu y que mientras viva adquirirÃ¡ experiencia para obtener bonificadores entre etapas o corridas. Si el chamÃ¡n muere otro ocuparÃ¡ su lugar con nivel 0.

En segundo lugar por medio de los botones derecho e izquierdo del ratÃ³n, una uniÃ³n y separaciÃ³n de formaciones hasta un maximo creo que de diez lÃ­neas o grupos; entre estos dos factores y cualidades conseguirÃ¡n una jugabilidad interesantisima.

En general su sistema de juego es muy reducido, rÃºstico y poco desarrollado para el tiempo real y el scroll que le va a tocar soportar, asÃ­ que suspenso sin dudar. En general y solamente se dedica a simbolizar por medio de algo muy breve el viaje de una tribu, la dificultades de una tribu en la prehistoria en ''caminar'' siempre en una direcciÃ³n; sin embargo dadas sus cualidades difundidas y su direcciÃ³n artÃ­stica se gana el derecho a ser un juego interesante y recomendable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099178052', 'num_games_owned': 635, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1474128824}
review:
[h1]Disclaimer![/h1]
This game was reviewed using a code/key sent by the publisher/developer (Using Keymailer) but this will [b]NOT[/b] and I will repeat [b]NOT!![/b] effect my thoughts/review on this game

[h1]The Tribe[/h1]
[b]is[/b] such a wonderful Hardcore-like Indie Game with Pixel Graphics! It starts off with the shaman that tells the tribe what they can and cannot do! You as the shaman control that as you explore the BC world. With only you and the tribe running towards the end of the level. The Controls are quite simple, hotkeys for actions (spears, torches) and left n right mouse clicks for group separation.

This game can be very hard and requires some time and skill in order to reach "The End".

[b]VIDEO REVIEW[/b]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hASLHX589u4

[b]Serio Plays: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLwdthOEbjnOOVzWyPL6qdn7IeMP3zoW56
[i]I would recommend checking out my review and my Serio Plays for more helpful review[/i]

[h1]Pros, Cons & Neutral![/h1]
[b]Pros: [/b]
â€¢ No FPS Lock 142 FPS+ tested
â€¢ Simple Resolution options 1080p!
â€¢ Pixel Graphics
â€¢ Cheap Price
â€¢ Developers are very nice and can sometimes can be active
â€¢ Nice Gameplay
â€¢ Good Sounds and Music

[b]Neutral: [/b]
â€¢ it's another Runner - Unless you like them

[b]Cons: [/b]
â€¢ No Borderless Window support
â€¢ Windowed Mode Fixed/Can't go higher than 1600 x 900 (no 1080p window mode)
â€¢ Sometimes the game can feel very unbalanced however the developers will listen to feedback
â€¢ No in-game options menu for controls (you can find in the launcher)
â€¢ No Adjustable Volume in-game (Simple On-Off)
â€¢ Gameplay quickly gets repetitive and boring
â€¢ No Blood Option

[h1]FPS LOCK?[/h1]
Nope, it's got no lock so you can play it at any refresh rate. Checked using Steam's FPS Counter.

[h1]Running Out of Food[/h1]
I don't know anything about balance but I felt like the food system is unbalanced. Most of the time I die because of lack of food on my screen. Deers, Dodo Birds etc. If you guys could increase the chances of finding some animals, bushes that would be nice. Yes it's hardcore like game but at least make it fair first. Without making the game too easy of course.

[h1]Steamified?[/h1]
Achievements, Trading Cards and it's even got Leaderboard! So Yes it's Steamified

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
I would say that if you love yourself some cavemen, shaman and a bunch of trying to avoid the rhinos. Then yes I would recommend this game. But if you're looking for good bargain for your money I would look else where, unless you absolutely love runners (even though they have been done 2 death, a lot of them are free flash games)

[h1]Keymailer & Developers[/h1]
https://www.keymailer.co I would like to thank Keymailer and the Developers for making this Review and Serio Plays possible! Many thanks! If you would like me to review your games contact me using the social links down below. Discord, Twitter would be the best for 24/7

[h1]Social Links: [/h1]
[b] Keep in touch and stay active! [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198055743640', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1473326224}
review:
Great approach to runner-genre! This is actually unusual and interesting game. There are many strange moments which are not explained in tutorial, but you should understand them after several attempts. The knowledge and skill is the main currency in this game. You die, and your people dies but knowledge and experience persists. I like this kind of games:)

PS having mobile version would be great :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198051906368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 110, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1479140404}
review: Very fun given the overall small size of the game. If there weren't so much pixel blood I'd recommend it for children, but isn't overwhelming for a young teen. I bought it on sale and would rate 4/5 because they seemed to really stretch on making it more adult for no reason at all. The game could have benefited from a little more explanation of the obstacles, but wasn't too hard to figure out that pretty much everything kills you or steals your food lol

author: {'steamid': '76561198028358584', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1472887582}
review:
Small fun game based around a really cool concept of an infinite runner, where you have to split your tribe and use your abilities to solve different types of obstacles.

At first, it's often going to seem like you're losing because you were unlucky with the map generation (not enough food, amirite?). But then you'll discover new ways to deal with things that you thought were impossible and you'll start getting consistently decent runs.

I feel like there could be more to it than just two game modes with leaderboards, but I can't really think of a way they could do a campaign or something like that. It's not something you're going to spend 10+ hours in, but it's definitely worth it at such a low price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132815190', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1473318823}

author: {'steamid': '76561198104354346', 'num_games_owned': 481, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1472814072}
review:
It's nowhere as epic or difficult as it is described. Once you know what to do for each obstacle, it becomes easy and repetitive. I've seen flash games with more depth than this. I am refunding.

Since someone asked, I'll put this here.
A list of flash games that I'd rather pay for than this game. They're all free though.

Sonny
Sonny 2
Mardek RPG Chapters 1-3
Pandemic
Pandemic 2
Infectinator (and its many sequels and spinoffs)
Chibi Knight
Epic Battle Fantasy 3
Portal: The Flash Edition
Alien Hominid
Pokemon Tower Defence
Road of the Dead
Road of the Dead 2
Super Mario 63
Super Smash Flash
Doodle God
Doodle Devil
Rebuild
Rebuild 2
Ching Chong Beautiful
Scale of The Universe 2 (Not really a game, but I'd rather spend money on that than this)
No One Has to Die
KOLM
One Chance

author: {'steamid': '76561198134487166', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 218, 'last_played': 1472893746}
review: Its a nice game with an interesting concept. You have a tribe which constantly travels downwards. You can split and join them into a group of one, two or much more. Also you can choose to arm your people with spear, torches or bare hands. You will have to adjust your strategy quickly, for example, a large group with spears will scare off deers whereas a small one will manage to hunt it. On the contrary, if you meet a group of other people, you really should have a large group, or they will kick your ass. Overall, the game is fun, but it has some cons. It is not always easy to understand how to split your group to get a specific resource (Is it on the 7/8 of the screen? Should I split into 8? or 9? ), and you can kill everyone very easiliy by making a single mistake.  The price tag is low, buy it and try it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169778814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1480015604}
review: This is literally GOOD runner game. (Yes, I have played a ton of games from many genres.) It is so because of its unique combination of story, humor,  style, gameplay variety, strategy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028267206', 'num_games_owned': 1177, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1472672671}
review:
Fun and Difficult indie game.

You are the leader of the tribe (The shaman)

TO feed your people you need to hunt animals and get food from bushes (or even sacrifice your own men) to keep the tribe growing

Over time you also get tokens which u use to get more food or restart a level if you die.

IF the shaman dies, another men will take his place.

You use only the mouse to control (Right click to split up and left to go together) aswell as Barehands (1) used to get bushes, 2 (Spears) to hunt animals, 3 (Fire to keep lions and stuff away), 4 (Sacrifice) to get more food by killing your men, 5 (to get more men, but need more food)

author: {'steamid': '76561198306603864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1474220705}
review:
For such a cheap price point, you could do worse. Fun, very quick game with some serious difficulty level. A full playthrough could take 15 minutes, so great for short bursts of gaming. 

6/10 overall, but i'm not one for runners.

author: {'steamid': '76561197988573955', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1472389773}
review: A very simple game, but addictive with a neat visual style and a decent bit of challenge. Think an infinite runner mixed with the resource management and map travel of Oregon Trail. I paid $4.79 and feel happy with what I'm getting for the price of a burger or two.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073189777', 'num_games_owned': 576, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1609790838}
review:
[b][u]The Tribe[/u][/b] ist ein Geschicklichkeit-basiertes Action Adventure, in der ein Meteor einen ganzen Steinzeitstamm bedroht. GlÃ¼cklicherweise erahnt der Schamane des Stamms diese Katastrophe und nun ist es unsere Aufgabe den Stamm in ein sicheres Land zu bringen.

Hierbei muss man verschiedene Gebiete durchqueren, zum Beispiel fruchtbares Land, Schneegebiete und WÃ¼sten. Je nachdem welchen Pfad man wÃ¤hlt (man hat nÃ¤mlich immer nach der ersten Mission die Wahl zwischen zwei Gebieten), existieren dort auf dem Weg mehr oder weniger Nahrung und Gefahren. Nahrung ist notwendig um den Stamm am Leben zu halten, weil sobald Nahrung auf 0 gefallen ist sterben die Stammesmitglieder wie die Fliegen. Aber auch mehrere Gefahren tÃ¶ten unsere SteinzeitmÃ¤nnchen in Sekundenbruchteilen. Zum Beispiel sollten wir nicht mit einem groÃŸen Rhino kuscheln, auch feindliche StÃ¤mme lassen sich nur friedlich Ã¼berzeugen (oder fÃ¼r Nahrung abschlachten *mwhahahaha*), falls wir in der Ãœberzahl sind. Ein Gebiet wird immer von oben nach unten statisch durchgelaufen und man kann die Bewaffnung der Truppen, sowie deren Aufteilung auf der horizontalen Achse wechseln. Hier ist sehr viel Geschick gefragt, da der Stamm mit Speeren in der Hand zwar Wild erlegen kann, aber BeerenbÃ¼sche zerstÃ¶ren wÃ¼rde. FÃ¼r das Sammeln von Beeren mÃ¼ssen die HÃ¤nde frei sein. Falls es mit der Nahrung absolut schlecht aussieht, kann man immer noch zur Not Kanibalismus betreiben und einige StammesangehÃ¶rige opfern. Hat man sehr viel Nahrung kann man auch den Stamm wieder vergrÃ¶ÃŸern, was aber auch den stÃ¤ndigen Nahrungsverbrauch wieder ankurbelt.

Eine besondere Herausforderung ist noch die Nacht. In dieser sieht man eigentlich nichts mehr von seinem Weg, auÃŸer man rÃ¼stet Fackeln aus, aber dann kann man gleichzeitig nicht jagen und verbrennt BeerenbÃ¼sche. Einige Gefahren wie SÃ¤belzahntiger lassen sich jedoch durch Feuer auch vertreiben.

Falls man das erste Mal es bis zu dem sicheren Land durch geschafft hat, wird ein zusÃ¤tzlicher Spielmodus freigeschaltet in dem man den kompletten Stamm in Sicherheit bringen muss (500 Leute).

Also wer auf Spiele steht in dem sein ReaktionsvermÃ¶gen gefragt ist und auch das Steinzeitszenario mag, der wird hiermit ein nettes kleines Spiel fÃ¼r nebenbei haben.

Hier fÃ¼r einen ersten Eindruck noch ein Video von meinen ersten Fails mit The Tribe ^^: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J42u5wfnvTs

author: {'steamid': '76561198087820850', 'num_games_owned': 324, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1472000796}
review:
So, "runner games" are not really my thing, but I decided to accept the offer to play it for free. I wouldn't say it's great, but there is potential there for fun if you already like these sorts of games.

PROS

- Nice retro graphical charm

- Simple premise

CONS

- Very short

- Really difficult in places, can feel unfair at times

- Enemy creatures not always clear if killable or not (frustrating)

- Tutorial could explain more

- Four pounds still feels expensive for what the game consists of

In all, it's pretty hard to recommend this game for anyone other than fans of these "runner" games. I wish there was a middle ground in the voting system not just thunbs up or down. So my review is "as is" in the game's current form and whether I personally like it or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001977944', 'num_games_owned': 294, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 630, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 526, 'last_played': 1473296799}
review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hnWJCOy5hqU&ab_channel=AndreasPeahc

This is a extension of my ending thoughts on my first look of this game.
I have played it now for around 2-3h and it has grown a bit on me. 
The game is a mix of a runner and managment games in the sense you need to avoid certain parts of the map while harvesting/killing other parts, the managment part is to make sure that your tribe does not grow to big for your food supplies or grow to small as to not be able to survive certain tribulations or get a low score.

If you enjoy runner games I would recommend the game at full price but if you are a bit on the edge I would say wait for a sale and the game might even be better by then since it's early access at the point of this review.

author: {'steamid': '76561198062232099', 'num_games_owned': 5821, 'num_reviews': 291, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1471208649}
review:
The Tribe is currently a part of Cubic Bundle's August Bundle. You can purchase this game and eight more for just US$1.50. Seven of the games contain Steam trading cards so you will get the vast majority of your purchase price back if you farm the cards. Consequently, before I delve any further into the review I wholeheartedly recommend that you pick up the bundle. You can get an additional bundle for just a $1 extra. The bundle ends at the end of August.

[h1]What is The Tribe?[/h1]

The Tribe is what the developers describe as a 'tactical hardcore runner' comprised of resource management and environment interactions. Players guide their tribes throughout each run with the primary objective of getting your shaman through to the end of each run. If the shaman dies then it is game over. In order to accomplish this mammoth task, players can separate and unite their tribe with a single press of the left and right mouse button. The game is played entirely with the mouse. Consequently, I suggest that the gameplay is relatively simple to learn and accessible to everyone.

[h1]Rewarding Experiences[/h1]

I know that there has been quite a lot of people play the game. However, as of writing, I am ranked 42nd in single run leaders and 37th in big pass leaders. Getting through to the end of a single run is mighty hard work. However, the longer that you are able to survive the greater the reward legitimately feels. Consequently, having any sort of success should be considered an achievement. I recommend that players who are experienced at both strategy and runner style games would find something that they would appreciate here.

[h1]Graphics & Sound[/h1]

One of the highlights to date are the pixelated graphics. They help provide the game with a retro feel. However, the gameplay feels new enough that in playing the game I am never given a 'been there, done that' type feeling. The originality in the game is quite striking. For being as simplistic as they look the animations are quite well done. The game is relatively easy on the eyes and is the basis of a number of good game design decisions.

I am also a fan of the sound that is featured within the game. The tribal music matches the theme and the atmosphere of the game perfectly. The other sounds are basic and again retro in style but they accomplish what the developers have set out to do.

[h1]Starvation[/h1]

The only problem that I have in the game is that of starvation. Runs can be doomed from the beginning and through absolutely no fault of your own. If you are not presented with food early enough in the run your tribesmen will starve to death. This happens too regularly for my liking. I had several runs in succession where food did not generate on the screen until after everyone had died. It isn't a case of not seeing an event generate but a case of it never generating. It seems like it's all a little bit of pot luck at times. Hopefully this changes throughout its further development.

[h1]Is it Steamified?[/h1]

There are 7 trading cards to collect as well as 11 Steam achievements to unlock. The game also incorporates the Steam Leaderboard system into its mechanics. This most certainly makes the game Steamified.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

I recently read a discussion on Reddit's /r/games about people finding it difficult to differentiate between a game being a bad title and a player simply not enjoying a game. This is a statement that I agree with to a certain extent. To be perfectly honest as much as I enjoyed certain aspects of The Tribe it isn't necessarily my cup of tea. However, to claim that it is a bad game would be entirely incorrect. It is a very solidly developed title to date. I am certain that its target audience would thoroughly enjoy it. In fact, I look forward to revisiting the game throughout its development. I'd like it to be an Early Access success. I think it deserves to be.

For similar reviews and your chance to win great giveaways please visit [url=http://www.steamified.com/]Steamified[/url]

review: A very nice game to pass the time. I also love the concept of how the shaman learns abilities over time, and every new shaman needs to relearn those abilitie/skills

author: {'steamid': '76561198292640430', 'num_games_owned': 133, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1471011612}
review:
I was lucky enough to get a key from the publisher, I had not seen or heard about this game before I received the key. The game is fun and is pretty neat to play.

The visuals and graphics remind me of those days in the 90s when I would play games like this, I could play this game for hours. The sacrificing and hunting elements are quite cool; although I received it for free it is well worth the price tag if not more

author: {'steamid': '76561198286017559', 'num_games_owned': 2641, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 241, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1470437677}
review:
Rather Intelligent, funny and I'm in love with those pixelated graphics, I'm a sucker for those kind of games. It's challenging, but it still feels like the game is missing something, I'm not going to be harsh as it is fairly new, and all in all, I loved this game.

8/10 Would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013119250', 'num_games_owned': 2232, 'num_reviews': 469, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1695936222}
review:
[b][h1]Complete failure[/h1][/b]
I received this title from developers, but its degree of f%#$@up made me so irritated, that I've decided to attack them for making this game... One of the most absurd and totally ill-games I've ever played in my entire game life, which has been going on for nearly 20 years. I'm playing and rating games for nearly 15 years and I've seen more RNG irritating game since many months.
First - we are traveling using group of primitive men on the basis of four lines and combine them or separate them. We need to avoid traps, get food, try to stay alive with our group. Thius idea isn't bad, but some maps are so drawn by the game system, that there is no option to win. We have to lose due to f$%$% up RNG system.
Often, the game does not respond to the keys fast enough, causing tons of irritation when we play at night and we have to react to approaching things very quickly. Another time, the levels are bad designed/randomized, so we must lose at all or lose most of our men.
The game is difficult, this is fact and a challenge, but RNG causes peals of irritation when we lose... Why? Because we have to lose. We must lose. Not because we did something wrong.
